description: From Middle English utmost, utemest [and other forms], from Old English ūtmest, ūtemest [and other forms], from ūt, ūte (“out; outdoors, outside”) + -mest (suffix meaning ‘furthest’, used to form superlatives of some adjectives) (and conflated with most). Ūt is derived from Proto-Germanic *ūt (“out, outward”), from Proto-Indo-European *úd (“out, outward”).

entries.meaning: Situated at the most distant limit; farthest, outermost.
examples: the utmost limits of the land
the utmost extent of human knowledge

entries.meaning: The greatest possible capability, extent, or quantity; maximum.
examples: at the utmost    to the utmost
